text: It works well as a PSA for consumer awareness of possible pathogens in food. However, its portrayal carries a very obvious political bias and overlooks possible problems with the regulation they support such as the ability to provide adequate food to consumers, negative health effects of chemicals and hormones that are required to solve this problem, and the economic practicality of their proposed legislation. In my opinion, it uses the food poisoning issue to scapegoat certain corporations to support their legislation for regulation. This proposed regulation isn’t necessarily bad, but the documentary does not give a fair or unbiased look at the issue.

Poisoned is an aggressively mediocre documentary oversold by its evocative title. This film features some interesting (albeit low-stakes) interviews, but they're edited so manipulatively that I feel embarrassed for the filmmakers and question the veracity of the points they were pushing. 
And one more thing...normally I wouldn't comment on the cinematography for a documentary, but every sit-down interview in Poisoned is inexplicably filmed with a bobbing handheld camera. It gives the interviews a casual, sitcom-like feel that seems downright disrespectful toward the people being interviewed (in particular the victims and families of victims).
There are plenty of other fish in the sea when it comes to food safety docs, and most of them are better than this one.
The subject was bacterial outbreaks. The title and description made it seem a lot broader in scope. Underwhelming...

"Poisoned" exposes the dark side of the food industry, revealing crime, corruption, negligence and waste. This wake-up call should leave viewers rightfully angered by a system that jeopardizes their health. While the film feels hopeless at times, it highlights progress and urges consumers to pressure Congress to make needed changes. The documentary excels in explaining the American food system and the current issues being faced, backed by a captivating score, sharp editing and top-notch production. It vividly showcases the severity of the U.S. food safety crisis and humanizes victims through their poignant interviews.

As someone who follows and reports on the impact of foodborne illness, I hope "Poisoned" sparks crucial attention and action. The alarm has been sounded on the country's largest streaming platform. How will American consumers respond?
